description.narrative:
The long-term goal of this program is to secure the ecosystem-based IPGs water provisioning, food security, and climate resilience for improved livelihoods. This involves multi-stakeholder governance of landscapes, including strong CSOs that represent the interests of vulnerable groups, women, and nature. To ensure that this type of land governance leads to sustainable land use, the program seeks to achieve various outcomes on inclusive and green business and government practices and policies. The joint strategic program objective is: effective CSO lobby&advocacy for business and government policies and practices that enable inclusive green development in selected landscapes and optimize ecological, social, and economic values. IUCN NL and WWF NL will help partner CSOs establish partnerships that lobby for and set up land governance based on a landscape-wide approach in which all stakeholders have a say. To ensure that CSOs can collaborate on an equal footing with the private (business) and public (government) sectors we will strengthen CSO capacities to engage and monitor all relevant stakeholders. In our approach we will aim to strengthen the enabling environment and the inclusiveness of decision-making for vulnerable groups and women. Finally, we provide a vision on the continuity and exit strategy of our interventions and discuss our main assumptions and risk-mitigation strategy.
The Shared Resources, Joint Solutions program focuses on safeguarding the ecosystem-based International Public Goods (IPGs) water provisioning, food security, and climate resilience in landscapes in 16 low- and lower-middle-income countries. As these IPGs are generated by ecosystems in identifiable landscapes, the program will take a landscape-based approach.

title.narrative: Inclusive and Green Business and Government practices and policies

description.narrative: Inclusive and Green Business and Government practices and policies
number of CSOs included in SPs programmes

comment.narrative: Accumulated DD6 indicator for total program period

Between 2017 and 2020, SRJS included 212 CSOs. The programme included a mix of community based, environmental, legal and Indigenous organisations that cross-fertilised each other. For example, the presence of gender-focused CSOs allowed the wider consortium to benefit from their expertise toward improved environmental results. All groups had a common continuous relationship with the programme, and all worked towards improved ecosystems and their services. SRJS also comprised various platforms, coalitions, cooperatives and forums, with communities, governments and private sector participation at international, national and local levels.

In 2017 we engaged with 59 more partners than at the end of 2016, leading up to a total of 154 partners in 2017 in 16 countries, 54 of whom are directly funded by IUCN NL and WWF NL. Our focus remains on ensuring a diverse, strong and coordinated civil society, which builds on each other’s strengths and roles. While all organisations in the end work towards the goal of improved ecosystems and its services, the SRJS programme works with a mix of community based, research&lobby, women, gender, religious, legal, knowledge based and indigenous organisations and various platforms, coalitions, cooperatives and forums, operating at both national and local levels.

In 2018, SRJS included 189 CSOs, of which 61 were new compared to 2017. The programme includes a mix of CSOs - community based, environmental, legal and Indigenous organisations that can cross-fertilise each other. For example, the presence of gender-focused CSOs in SRJS allows the wider consortium to benefit from their programmatic expertise for the benefit of better environmental results. All have a common continuous relationship with the programme, and all work towards improved ecosystems and its services. The programme also comprises various platforms, coalitions, cooperatives and forums, with communities, governments and private sector participation operating at both international, national and local levels.

In 2019, SRJS included 202 CSOs, of which 19 were new compared to 2017. The programme includes a mix of CSOs - community based, environmental, legal and Indigenous organisations that can cross-fertilise each other. For example, the presence of gender-focused CSOs in SRJS allows the wider consortium to benefit from their programmatic expertise for the benefit of better environmental results. All have a common continuous relationship with the programme, and all work towards improved ecosystems and its services. The programme also comprises various platforms, coalitions, cooperatives and forums, with communities, governments and private sector participation operating at both international, national and local levels.

description.narrative: number of CSOs with increased L&A capacities

comment.narrative: Accumulated DD5 indicator for total program period

In 2017, 69 partners have thus far specifically strengthened their capacities in lobby and advocacy. Capacity development revolves around six central themes, namely 1) support to CSOs for business engagement; 2) communication strategy; 3) lobby and advocacy strategy; 4) innovative monitoring methods; 5) Strategic Environmental Assessment for dialogue and action; and 6) applied gender and inclusiveness awareness. A central assumption in the Theory of Change of SRJS is that lobby and advocacy is more effective when CSOs have a strong knowledge base and are able to engage in dialogue with a broad group of stakeholders.

The launch point of all SRJS interventions is to build civil society partners’ lobby & advocacy (L&A) skills to secure the future of International Public Goods. In 2018, 160 civil society partners have strengthened their capacities around four central themes: 1) engagement with businesses and the financial sector, 2) L&A; 3) innovative monitoring methods; and 4) Strategic Environmental Assessments for dialogue and action. Successful capacity strengthening for L&A is embedded in broader mechanisms and processes that facilitate the application, consolidation and sharing of learning by those involved. A mix of capacity building measures gives the best results to advance ecosystem based socio-political skills.

The launch point of all SRJS interventions is to build civil society partners’ lobby & advocacy (L&A) skills to secure the future of International Public Goods. In 2019, 175 civil society partners have strengthened their capacities around four central themes: 1) engagement with businesses and the financial sector, 2) L&A; 3) innovative monitoring methods; and 4) Strategic Environmental Assessments for dialogue and action. Successful capacity strengthening for L&Ais embedded in broader mechanisms and processes that facilitate the application, consolidation and sharing of learning by those involved. A mix of capacity building measures gives the best results to advance ecosystem based socio-political skills.

The launch point of all SRJS interventions was to help improve civil society partners’ L&A skills to secure the future of ecosystem-based IPGs. During the course of the programme, 191 civil society partners strengthened their L&A capacities, revolving around four key themes: 1) private sector engagement; 2) lobby and advocacy capacities; 3) innovative monitoring; and 4) strategic environmental assessment and environmental and social impact assessment. In addition, efforts were made to strengthen capacities for inclusive and just conservation. Successful capacity strengthening for L&A was embedded in broader mechanisms and processes that facilitated the application, consolidation and sharing of learning. A mix of capacity building measures gave the best results to advance ecosystem based socio-political skills.

description.narrative: number of laws, policies and norms, implemented for sustainable and inclusive development.

comment.narrative: In 2018, SRJS partners contributed to changed practices through the implementation of 77 laws, policies or norms of targeted governments (in 60% of the cases), private sector (14%) and societal actors (25%), such as communities. Half of the changes took place at local/district level, 40% at national level and 10% at international level. Implementation mostly related to improved practices in the extractives, agriculture and infrastructure sectors for the benefit of ecosystems and people, depending on the services of ecosystems. For example, in Bolivia, a new local water fund was consolidated in collaboration with water utilities, the municipal government and the civic water committee. The fund aims to preserve the health of the forest in watershed ‘recharge’ areas for the water sources of the town Chochis.

In 2019, SRJS partners contributed to changed practices through the implementation of 106 laws, policies or norms of targeted governments (in 50% of the cases), private sector (9%) and community actors (42%). This is a strong increase compared to previous year. Three quarters of the changes took place at the local level and a quarter at the provincial and national level. Implementation mostly related to improved practices in the extractives, agriculture and fisheries sectors for the benefit of ecosystems and people, depending on the services of ecosystems. For example, SRJS has been successful in constituting a formal cooperation between the Government of Benin - represented by the Marine Forces -and the Sea Shepherd Society to combat illegal fishing in the Beninese coastal and high sea, resulting in a joint enforcement mission.

Over the course of the programme, SRJS partners contributed to changed practices through the implementation of 275 laws, policies or norms of targeted governments (in 45% of the cases), private sector (10%) and community actors (42%). About three quarters of the changes took place at the local level and a quarter at the provincial and national level. Implementation mostly related to improved practices in the extractives, agriculture and fisheries sectors for the benefit of ecosystems and people depending on the services of ecosystems. For example, SRJS has been successful in constituting a formal cooperation between the Government of Benin - represented by the Marine Forces - and the Sea Shepherd Society to combat illegal fishing in the Beninese coastal zone and high seas, resulting in a joint enforcement mission.

SRJS partners contributed to 61 changes in practices of targeted governments, private sector and societal actors in 2017. One third involved the implementation of policies, laws and practices, whereas two thirds involved changes in existing practices and actions. Almost all changes came about in CSO partnerships with governments and a large majority took place at a local level. The implementation of policies and the improvement in practices mostly related to sectors such as infrastructure, agriculture, financial and extractives, for example in Tanzania where the responsible ministry closed illegal mining operations and illegal settlements in Msaginya forest reserve after campaigning and lobby efforts of SRJS partners.

description.narrative: number of laws, policies and norms/attitudes, blocked, adopted, improved for sustainable and inclusive development

comment.narrative: In 2017 SRJS partners contributed to 89 changes in the development, approval, blocking or improvement of laws, policies and regulations, at local, regional, national and international level. Around half of the changes were measured in Asian countries where SRJS works, around 30% took place in African countries and around 20% took place in Latin-American countries. Local governments often welcome the expert support of our partners in drafting these instruments to improve governance. Fruitful collaboration and dialogue with governments toward specific goals requires patience and persistence, but is for example in Bolivia resulting in a municipal plan that includes strategies and actions to ensure climate resilience.

In 2018, SRJS partners contributed to 217 blocked, adopted or improved laws, policies and norms/attitudes (almost a threefold increase on 2017). Most changes (61%) took places at the local/district level, 30% at national level and 9% at international level. These local level changes often contribute to agreements for the sustainable use of scarce ecosystem resources such as water. They also contribute to social inclusion, such as of Indigenous peoples, youth and women. In Uganda, for example, the Hoima District local government council passed a resolution to develop an ordinance for food security as a move to promote community rights to food and land while maintaining vital ecosystems and their services.

In 2019, SRJS partners contributed to 189 blocked, adopted or improved laws, policies and norms/attitudes. Most changes (59%) took places at the local level, 13% at provincial level, 22% at national level and 5% at supra-national and international level. These local level changes often contribute to agreements for the sustainable use of scarce ecosystem resources such as water. They also contribute to social inclusion, such as of Indigenous peoples, youth and women. For example in Bolivia, a new law enacted by the Indigenous Autonomous Government of the Charagua district declared 1.2 million hectares as a conservation area. This law allows for the protection of a continuous conservation area of more than 6 million hectares in the Gran Chaco region. It is the first protected area thus created.

SRJS partners contributed to 575 blocked, adopted or improved laws, policies and norms/attitudes between 2017 and 2020. Most changes (approximately 60%) took places at the local level, 6% at provincial level, 27% at national level and 6% at supra-national and international level. The local level changes often contributed to agreements for the sustainable use of scarce ecosystem resources such as water. They also contributed to social inclusion, such as of Indigenous peoples, youth and women. For example in Bolivia, a new law enacted by the Indigenous Autonomous Government of the Charagua district declared 1.2 million hectares as a conservation area. This law allowed for the protection of a continuous conservation area of more than 6 million hectares in the Gran Chaco region. It is the first protected area thus created.

description.narrative: number of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage.

comment.narrative: In 2017 SRJS partners contributed to 39 changes in relation to agenda-setting or space to engage with the private sector and governments. The SRJS program also supported communities in these countries to be more confident to engage in dialogue with other stakeholders. While dialogue is often central to influencing the private sector, partner CSOs will at times use litigation or other forms of pressure to promote compliance. Where dialogue is the modus operandi, we tend to see a more gradual change in attitude and behaviour, for example in Indonesia, where communities engage in dialogue with government actors to develop their livelihoods, whereas previous interaction between the two was virtually non-existent.

In 2018 SRJS partners contributed to 66 changes in relation to agenda-setting or space to engage with the private sector and governments. In some cases, governments learned to listen to and see the CSOs as more of an ally in strengthening their own governance, rather than a threat. In Burkina Faso, for example, the solution-oriented attitude of partners won them a place at the table with the environmental agency on dam development. In Cambodia, the space created for CSOs, resulted in the Ministry of Environment incorporating at least half of CSO inputs into the latest draft version of the Environmental and Natural Resources Code.

In 2019 SRJS partners contributed to 70 changes in relation to agenda-setting or space to engage with the private sector and governments. This is a strong increase compared to previous years. In some cases, governments learned to listen to and see the CSOs as more of an ally in strengthening their own governance, rather than a threat. For example in Zambia, Lower Kafue Basin stakeholders, including 11 chiefs, gave their support to the Lower Kafue River Basin Report Card during the community mobilization and information dissemination exercise organised by WWF Zambia and People’s Action Forum. In the Philippines, a Women’s Cooperative in Aroroy, Masbate, independently articulated its concerns to prioritize livelihood over mining during the Commission on Human Rights Inquiry regarding social and environmental injustices caused by a large mining company.

In total, SRJS partners contributed to 190 changes in relation to agenda-setting or space to engage with the private sector and governments. In some cases, governments learned to listen to and see the CSOs as more of an ally in strengthening their own governance, rather than a threat. For example in Zambia, Lower Kafue Basin stakeholders, including 11 chiefs, gave their support to the Lower Kafue River Basin Report Card during the community mobilisation and information dissemination exercise organised by WWF Zambia and People’s Action Forum. In the Philippines, a Women’s Cooperative in Aroroy, Masbate, independently articulated its concerns to prioritise livelihoods over mining during the Commission on Human Rights Inquiry regarding social and environmental injustices caused by a large mining company.
